title: Theresa May on course to be next U.K. prime minister after rival quits
content:
LONDON — British Prime Minister David Cameron said Monday that he will resign by Wednesday , paving the way for Home Secretary Theresa May to succeed him as the United Kingdom 's second female leader .
Cameron 's announcement came just hours after May 's only competitor for Conservative Party leader and prime minister — Energy Minister Andrea Leadsom — dropped out of the running .
U.K. 's next prime minister , Theresa May , formidable like 'Iron Lady ' Thatcher
Graham Brady , who leads the committee overseeing the election of the new Conservative leader , said May was confirmed by the panel .
Speaking to supporters after the latest political twists and turns , May said she is “ honored and humbled ” to be chosen as the new leader .
Leadsom said she did not believe she had sufficient support within the party to lead a strong and stable government .
Party lawmakers last week narrowed the choice of candidates for leader to May and Leadsom . Cameron had announced he would resign by October shortly after the June 23 referendum supported a U.K. exit , or Brexit , from the 28-nation European Union . Cameron led the campaign to remain in the EU .
May , who also supported remaining in the EU , won 199 votes Thursday from party lawmakers , while Leadsom , who backed the campaign to leave , had 84 .
“ Brexit means Brexit , and we ’ re going to make a success of it , ” May said Monday , as she promised to deliver “ a strong , new positive vision for the future of our country . ”
She did elaborate on her plans for pursuing the formal split with the EU .
Leadsom , 53 , apologized to May on Monday after suggesting in an interview with the Times of London that being a mother made her a better candidate for prime minister than May , who has no children . Last week , Leadsom denied embellishing her resume regarding her 25-year career in finance following media reports that she had done so .
Theresa May : 5 things to know about likely new U.K. leader
May , 59 , will become the U.K. 's first female prime minister since Margaret Thatcher , known as the `` Iron Lady , '' governed from 1979 to 1990 . Thatcher died in 2013 .
Boris Johnson , a leading `` leave '' campaigner and former London mayor , was the favorite to replace Cameron , but dropped out of the leadership race after a close colleague claimed he lacked leadership skills for the top post . Johnson then gave May his backing .
`` Theresa May will provide the authority and the leadership necessary to unite the Conservative party and take the country forward in the coming weeks and months , '' Johnson said in a statement .
Tim Loughton , Leadsom 's campaign manager , accused some Conservative Party members and journalists of making `` an onslaught of often very personal attacks '' against her .
`` Using spin and underhand tactics against decent people whose prime motivation is to serve has for too long undermined the confidence of the public in our politics , '' he said in a statement .
The new leader was originally scheduled to be chosen by 150,000 Conservative Party members on Sept. 9 .

Jane Onyanga-Omara

USA TODAY

LONDON — British Prime Minister David Cameron said Monday that he will resign by Wednesday, paving the way for Home Secretary Theresa May to succeed him as the United Kingdom's second female leader.

Cameron's announcement came just hours after May's only competitor for Conservative Party leader and prime minister — Energy Minister Andrea Leadsom — dropped out of the running.

U.K.'s next prime minister, Theresa May, formidable like 'Iron Lady' Thatcher

Graham Brady, who leads the committee overseeing the election of the new Conservative leader, said May was confirmed by the panel.

Speaking to supporters after the latest political twists and turns, May said she is “honored and humbled” to be chosen as the new leader.

Leadsom said she did not believe she had sufficient support within the party to lead a strong and stable government.

Party lawmakers last week narrowed the choice of candidates for leader to May and Leadsom. Cameron had announced he would resign by October shortly after the June 23 referendum supported a U.K. exit, or Brexit, from the 28-nation European Union. Cameron led the campaign to remain in the EU.

May, who also supported remaining in the EU, won 199 votes Thursday from party lawmakers, while Leadsom, who backed the campaign to leave, had 84.

“Brexit means Brexit, and we’re going to make a success of it,” May said Monday, as she promised to deliver “a strong, new positive vision for the future of our country.”

She did elaborate on her plans for pursuing the formal split with the EU.

Leadsom, 53, apologized to May on Monday after suggesting in an interview with the Times of London that being a mother made her a better candidate for prime minister than May, who has no children. Last week, Leadsom denied embellishing her resume regarding her 25-year career in finance following media reports that she had done so.

Theresa May: 5 things to know about likely new U.K. leader

May, 59, will become the U.K.'s first female prime minister since Margaret Thatcher, known as the "Iron Lady," governed from 1979 to 1990. Thatcher died in 2013.

Boris Johnson, a leading "leave" campaigner and former London mayor, was the favorite to replace Cameron, but dropped out of the leadership race after a close colleague claimed he lacked leadership skills for the top post. Johnson then gave May his backing.

"Theresa May will provide the authority and the leadership necessary to unite the Conservative party and take the country forward in the coming weeks and months," Johnson said in a statement.

Tim Loughton, Leadsom's campaign manager, accused some Conservative Party members and journalists of making "an onslaught of often very personal attacks" against her.

"Using spin and underhand tactics against decent people whose prime motivation is to serve has for too long undermined the confidence of the public in our politics," he said in a statement.

The new leader was originally scheduled to be chosen by 150,000 Conservative Party members on Sept. 9.
